text: hi everyone and the
husband and it's time for a review of
the new shad album flying colors this
guy is a rapper of Kenyan descent who
hails from London Ontario Canada I
believe this is his fourth full-length
studio LP and easily this guy is one of
the brightest and sees that our
neighbors to the north have to offer yes
Flo he has personality the lyrics he
dishes out usually have a pretty sharp
sense of humor and his vocals his
cadence just the sound of his voice just
has a really friendly demeanor like whoa
I kind of want to hang out with this
dude and be his best friend it's that
feeling that that separates shad from
most emcees out there today now as you
guys already know I love grit in my
music I love experimentation and sadly
shad offers up very little of both
however I don't really necessarily mind
emcees that are playful or really smart
or poppy and even though shad dabbles
and all of these things he's an emcee
who always comes off to me as being
just a little less than exciting however
maybe flying colors is the closest he's
come to doing that so far considering
how many serious highlights there are on
this thing like the intro which has an
explosive string back instrumental I
love the rolling drum machine beats on
this thing really detailed noisy in the
first verse the shad drops on this thing
incredibly fast and passionate usually
not rapping this fast which he also
makes note of and I'm loving some of the
lines on here some of the wordplay like
not saying they're Nazis but how can
they not see that it's a white world
they don't even want that coffee black
he also says that he's a vet but not the
type of it that's feeling these cats and
shad has three other pretty good
features on this track as well Lisa Bob
singer hope I'm pronouncing her name
correctly
seems pretty beautifully over this very
glistening chorus Ian Ken how has this
beautiful bit of spoken word in the
midst of this track and I think maybe
the shakiest verse on this thing maybe
not necessarily 100% necessary on this
thing is que haces verse which closes
things out and while his wordplay isn't
bad on the set of bars I guess I wasn't
crazy about his flow and just sort of
the heaviness of his voice and the
distortion that really made him stick
out past the beat on this thing to me
not really a pleasant way to finish this
song off still it is one of my favorite
tracks on this LP along with fam Jam a
song whose instrumental feels like a mix
between hip-hop grooves and some
turntable cuts and
cake instrumental yep kind of feels like
cake and the song is essentially an ode
to immigrants people who have come to
America looking to make a better life
for themselves and shad especially
delves into his own Kenyan roots talking
about how we've had immigrants that have
gone from donated clothes to caps and
gowns and how his mother moved them away
from where they were and shad growing up
realizing that there was sort of
fighting turmoil murder going on in the
motherland stylin not a bad song either
one of the lead singles off of this LP
shad with Socrates on the hook singing
very soulful II and with a pretty sharp
beat and a heavy buzzing bassline we
essentially have shad spinnin bar after
bar after witty ass bar saying he's like
a combo of Nickelback and The Diplomats
or even the line about how he runs like
a Kenyan because he's Kenyan ask his
mama and I love his bars on here about
how somebody may love his music but they
hate
rapidly addressing that sort of weird
moment when you're dealing with somebody
who doesn't quite understand that there
is rap music out there that is deeper
and more emotional and sort of moves
beyond what the lyrics you're usually
hearing and the mainstream stuff is I
especially love the last verse on this
track too with all the acronyms at the
end really nice theme at the end of this
track and shad sort of passes and
delivers a lot of bars with flying
colors and the song love means while
maybe not the most hard-hitting and
sharp instrumental of the bunch it does
kind of get the job done with its groove
and its really beautiful soul sample is
one of the most moving tracks on this LP
and kicks off with a stellar verse from
an MC a fem c by the name of eternia she
has maybe the most urgent passionate
delivery of any guests on this LP and
though her delivery is aggressive the
verse that she drops here about love is
freakin gorgeous and shad follows up
with talking about love in the abstract
a little bit rapping about how love is
something that is easy to talk about
easy to rap about easy to pretend you're
romantic and you're this and you're that
but love is something that is in fact
when you really get down to is hard to
live up to this is the kind of thing
that no matter how disappointed I may or
may not be with the shad album or a shad
track that I'm like yeah this this guy
is awesome he finally finishes the album
off with this 7-minute closure which is
a lot more hard-hitting and has some
pretty personal energetic and nostalgic
bars throughout but when it comes to the
sadder or more toned down tracks on here
he just doesn't bring the emotion that
really makes these songs have an impact
or makes them moving to listen to like
the song y'all know me which to me
energetically is just too
middle-of-the-road to be memorable I
like a lot of shads bars but the
instrumental and the flow and again the
energy of this track just isn't there
and the song he says she say another
track that lyrically is interesting a
song about how it seems like shad is
rapping from the standpoint of a younger
version of themself rapping trying to
make it but dealing with a girl in a
relationship who is sort of putting up
with him being childish and chasing
these pipe dreams the instrumental here
doesn't really give much weight to the
story especially with the smooth jazz
trumpet playing toward the end and the
song dream while I think it kind of
continues on this theme of shad
succeeding and achieving in hip-hop
music and in his career but feeling
unfulfilled despite that I'm liking the
concept part that's going on here but
again instrumentally and flow wise I'm
left sort of underwhelmed shad has some
sad tracks on here but in his most
emotive moments he feels so close to
indifference and I could see him having
some success pulling tracks like this
out onto his albums especially
considering how well the song progress
goes this is one of the longer and
sadder tracks on this LP has a pretty
interesting vocal and instrumental
interlude on the back end and it's a
pretty deep track for shad talking about
mis-education lies hip hop as an art
form kind of dying I love how he uses
the hook from American Pie on here
delivers it in a really sad way and the
rising strings on this very propulsive
beat give this song a lot of energy that
I feel like some of the more toned-down
tracks on here just don't have
truthfully there isn't really anything
on this LP that I dislike yeah there are
moments here where shad seems a little
too playful or a little too vanilla but
that's also part of his appeal because
with that question this dude is clever
he is hopping on some of his most
ambitious instrumentals yet on this
thing he's got concepts themes bars
personality wise and his rhymes he seems
pretty down-to-earth if only his
delivery and just sort of his
presentation was a little bit more
thrilling that's it I'm feeling a light
a decent seven on this thing ah
transition but if you've given this LP a
listen what did you think of it still
what it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantan Oh shad
forever
